bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, May 10, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 68. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia, MAY 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.

p.add: See his No. 63, of Feb'y 19, 1901 Acknowledged June 15, 1901.

div1.p: Subject. Transmitted of copies of all correspondence, in relation to the estate of the late William Porker; between the Administrator James (George) H. Lewis; the State Department, Monrovia, and this Consulate General..
No. 68. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; May 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to transmit, herewith, copies of all correspondence, relative to the estate of the late William Porker, between James (George by mistake on my part) H. Lewis, the Administrator of the esstate; the State Department, Monrovia, and this Consulate General.
By a close reading of my letter to James H. Lewis, the Administrator, in whose house Porker, resided and diedl you will observe that

that I set up the claim that Porker was and died an American citizen. You will further observe, that James H. Lewis, the Administrator, in none of his replies, as Administrator; denies my claim that Porker was an American citizen; but tacitly admits my claim by promising to forward the effects of the deceased to this Consulate General.

In my No 4/1901, Miscellaneous, January 29, 1901, to the State Department, Monrovia; complaining of the silency and non action of the Administrator; the State Department, in reply informed me that the Attorney General, had been instructed to correspond with the said James H. Lewis, the
the Administrator; advising him to comply with the terms of the law &c.

In reply to the Attorney General's letter; upon inquiry, at the Executive Mansion, the President informed me that James H. lewis, the Administrator had answered the Attorney General; informing him that he, James H. Lewis, had sold the effects of the deceased, and would soon come down and make a report to the Attorney General, which he James H. Lewis, the Administrator, thought, would be satisfacotry to the Attorney General. Having reeived such information from the President, I demurred, at the expressed desire to make his report to the Attorney General, and filed my Protest,

Protest No. 10/1901, Miscellaneous, March 16, 1901, to the State Department, Monrovia. To this Protest, the Liberian Government, to date, has failed to make a direct reply, to this Consulate General. It has, however, indirectly, replied, by instructing the Hon. R. J. B. Watson, the Superintendent of Grand Cape Mount Territory, to cause the said James H. Lewis,, the Administrator, to make an immediate report, transmitting the proceeds &c of said estate, direct to me.
Upon the receipt of the report of James H. Lewis, the Administrator, I was confined to my bed, very sick; but without opening the report; I directed the Secretary of the Legation to
